results.name: 1/4 of the number of primitive integral quadruples with sum = 3*n and sum of squares = 3*n^2.
comment: Conjecture: a(n) is multiplicative, with a(2) = 1, a(2^k) = 0 for k>=2, and for k >= 1 and p an odd prime, a(p^k) = p^(k-1)*a(p), with a(p) = p+1 for p == 5 (mod 6), a(p) = p-1 for p=1 (mod 6), and a(3) = 3.  It would be nice to have a proof of this.
This sequence applies also to the case sum = n and ssq = n^2. [Edited by _Petros Hadjicostas_, Apr 20 2020]
link: Andrew Howroyd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..500

Petros Hadjicostas, Slight modification of Mallows' R program. [To get the total counts for n = 1 to 120, type gc(1:120, 3, 3), where r = 3 and s = 3. To get the 1/4 of these counts, type gc(1:120, 3, 3)[,3]/4. As stated in the comments, we get the same sequence with r = 1 and s = 1, i.e., we may type gc(1:120, 1, 1)[,3]/4.]
Colin Mallows, R programs for A278081-A278086.
example: For the case r = s = 3, we have 4*a(3) = 12 because of (1,1,3,4) (12 permutations). Indeed, 1 + 1 + 3 + 4 = 9 = 3*3 and 1^2 + 1^2 + 3^2 + 4^2 = 27 = 3*3^2.
mathematica: a[n_] := Module[{s}, s = 3 n^2; Sum[q[3 n - i - j, s - i^2 - j^2, GCD[i, j]] , {i, -sqrtint[s], sqrtint[s]}, {j, -sqrtint[s - i^2], sqrtint[s - i^2]}]/4];
Table[an = a[n]; Print[n, " ", an]; an, {n, 1, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 20 2020, after _Andrew Howroyd_ *)
program: a(n)={my(s=3*n^2); sum(i=-sqrtint(s), sqrtint(s), sum(j=-sqrtint(s-i^2), sqrtint(s-i^2), q(3*n-i-j, s-i^2-j^2, gcd(i,j)) ))/4} \\ _Andrew Howroyd_, Aug 02 2018
